In the WFM's 1903-05 struggle in Colorado, with martial law once again in force, two declarations uttered by the National Guard and recorded for posterity further clarified the relationship of the mine operator's enforcement army — provided courtesy of the Colorado governor — to the workers. When union attorneys asked the courts to free illegally imprisoned strikers, Adjutant General Sherman Bell declared, "[[Habeas corpus]] be damned, we'll give 'em [[Autopsy|post mortems]]."<Ref>Carlson, 62.</Ref> Reminded of the Constitution, one of Bell's junior officers declared coolly, "To hell with the Constitution. We're not going by the Constitution."<Ref>Carlson, 63.</Ref>

General Bell had been the manager of one of the coal mines in Cripple Creek where the strike was taking place.<Ref>All That Glitters: Class, Conflict, and Community in Cripple Creek, Elizabeth Jameson, pp 140.</Ref> It wasn't any surprise to Haywood that soldiers seemed to be working in the interests of the employers, he'd seen that before.<Ref>Carlson, 65.</Ref> But when the Colorado legislature acknowledged the complaints of organized labor and passed an [[Eight-hour day|eight hour]] law, the Colorado supreme court declared it unconstitutional.<Ref>Carlson, 64.</Ref> So the WFM took the issue to the voters, and 72 percent of the state's voters approved the referendum.<Ref>Carlson, 65.</Ref> But the Cololorado government ignored the referendum.<Ref>Carlson, 65.</Ref>

Although active in the Socialist Party, for Haywood the socialist philosophy — which WFM supporter the Rev. Fr. [[Thomas J. Hagerty]] called ''"slowcialism"'' — didn't seem hard-nosed enough for his labor instincts. Haywood preferred a philosophy arrived at through the hard-scrabble experiences of the workers. "I've never read Marx's Capital," Haywood liked to say, "but I have the marks of capital all over me."<Ref>Lukas, 1997, pp. 233.</Ref>
